Graphical abstract We summarized three strategies, including tuning electronic structure, surface structure, and coordination environment, to regulate the adsorption of intermediates to improve the performance of the Cu-based catalyst for generating C2 products. Electrochemical reduction of CO2 (CO2RR) to high value-added chemicals is an effective way to remove excess CO2 from the atmosphere. Due to the unique propensity of Cu for valuable hydrocarbons, Cu-based electrocatalysts are the most potential catalysts that allow the conversion of CO2 into a variety of C2 products such as ethylene and ethanol. Rational design of Cu-based catalysts can improve their directional selectivity to C2 products. Hence, in this review, we summarize the recent progress in the mechanistic studies of Cu-based catalysts on reducing CO2 to C2 products. We focus on three key strategies for efficiently enhancing electrocatalytic performance of Cu-based catalysts, including tuning electronic structure, surface structure, and coordination environment. The correlation between the structural characteristics of Cu-based catalysts and their activity and selectivity to C2 products is discussed. Finally, we discuss the challenges in the field of CO2 electroreduction to C2 products and provide the perspectives to design efficient Cu-based catalysts in the future. Keywords Carbon dioxide Cu-based catalysts Mechanisms Active site regulation 1 Introduction With the combustion of fossil fuels since the industrial revolution, the carbon that had been removed from the carbon cycle was released into the atmosphere in the form of carbon dioxide, breaking the balance of the carbon cycle [1]. By Aug. 2021, the concentration of atmospheric CO2 rapidly reached 414.4 ppm, which was much higher than the 280.0 ppm in the 1760s [2]. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) predicted that by the end of the 25th century, the CO2 concentration would reach 590.0 ppm and the average global temperature could rise 1.9 °C [3]. Various chemical methods have been adopted to reduce the concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere, including electrocatalytic, photocatalytic, photoelectrochemical, biocatalytic, and organocatalytic reactions [4]. Among them, understanding CO2 conversion from an electrochemical perspective has received widespread attention, because CO2RR can convert CO2 into highly value-added chemicals in mild reaction conditions and the source of hydrogen is pollution-free water. Furthermore, it is a promising concept to store renewable power resources into chemical bonds with high-energy density [5]. To improve energy efficiency, reaction selectivity, and total conversion of CO2 processes, various metals have been widely investigated. In 1985, Hori et al. [6] first reported the detailed analysis of products catalyzed by various pure metal electrodes. He and co-workers divided the metals into four categories: (1) Sn, Pb, Hg, In, and Cd are used to selectively catalyze the production of formic acid. (2) Au, Ag, Zn, and Ga are used to selectively catalyze the production of CO; (3) Ni, Fe, Pt, and Al are used to selectively catalyze the production of hydrogen evolution reaction; (4) Cu and Cu alloys are used to selectively catalyze the production of multi-carbon products. Compared with other metals, Cu has the unique ability to produce a wide variety of C1/C2+ products via adjusting applied potential due to the positive adsorption energy for *H and negative adsorption energy for *CO [7]. However, the large overpotentials, multiple products, unsatisfactory selectivity of Cu-based catalyst as well as poor stability under reaction conditions limit their application in CO2RR [8,9]. For example, Thomas F. Jaramillo and his co-workers [10] first identified 16 different reaction products from a Cu surface, representing a poor selectivity for CO2RR. They also reported that a large overpotential of ∼1 V was required to obtain a mix of major and minor products. In addition, most Cu-based catalysts are only stable for several hours due to structural disruption, active-phase loss, and poisoning, hence limiting their practical applications [11–13]. In order to enhance the electrocatalytic performance of Cu-based catalysts, various strategies have been proposed, including tuning the particle size and shape [14], crystal facets [15], oxidation state [16], and electronic structure [17] of Cu. The ultimate aim of CO2RR for Cu-based catalysts is to meet the requirements of techno-economic analysis (TEA), which is faraday efficiency (FE) > 90%, cell voltage <1.8 V, current density >300 mA cm−2, and stability >80000 h [18]. In this review, we discuss the structure-property relationship of Cu-based catalysts and attempt to provide well-effective strategies to rationally devise Cu-based catalysts. Jaramillo et al. had found that seven C2 products of CO2RR on Cu-based electrocatalysts were observed, including ethylene, ethanol, acetaldehyde, ethylene glycol, glycolaldehyde, glyoxal, and acetate [10]. Among these products, ethylene and ethanol are two major C2 products, while other C2 compounds account for much lower yields [19]. Ethylene and ethanol are also the most promising target products when considering economic competitiveness [20]. Thus, we mainly discuss the generation of ethylene and ethanol products in this review. Firstly, we briefly discuss the recent progress in the reaction mechanisms toward C2 products of Cu-based catalysts. During the multielectron transfer of CO2RR, the adsorption energies of reaction intermediates, such as *CO, *COOH, and *OCHO, are widely believed to determine the reaction paths [5,21]. However, Cu has moderate binding energies for most intermediates, leading to the parallelism of multiple reaction pathways and a mixture of hydrocarbons products [22]. Despite both experimental and computational studies that have been conducted to understand the reaction mechanisms in recent years, the precise conversion mechanisms of CO2 into C2 products remain particularly controversial due to the complexity of intermediate structures. Herein, according to the differences in C–C coupling of intermediates, we briefly introduce the three most widely accepted reaction mechanisms on Cu-based catalysts for CO2RR: dimerization of *CO, coupling of two *CH2 species (carbene mechanism), and insertion of CO in *CHO species. Since the intrinsic properties significantly affect the generation and adsorption of the intermediates, hence impacting the reaction paths, we accordingly categorize the design approaches into three strategies from the following perspectives to improve the catalytic activity of Cu-based catalysts, including tuning electronic structure, surface structure, and coordination environment (Scheme 1 ). Finally, we discuss the challenges and perspectives of Cu-based catalysts in the field of theoretical calculation and in-situ technology and hope to facilitate future research and application for sustainable CO2 electroreduction. 2 Mechanism of CO2 reduction on Cu-based electrocatalysts 2.1 Thermodynamic and kinetic analysis of CO2 reduction CO2 is a linear molecule with two equivalent C=O bonds (750 kJ mol−1) [23]. The σ bond and the delocalized bond between C and O shorten the bond length as well as render the C–O bond some triple bond characters, thus leading to thermodynamic stability under atmospheric conditions [24]. As the highest valent oxide of carbon, CO2 can be reduced to various products (CO, HCOOH, C2H4, C2H5OH) by applying negative potentials [5,25]. Table 1 lists the standard potentials for reducing CO2 to different products at standard conditions (1.0 atm and 25 °C). It shows that the applied potential strongly affects product selectivity. If the reaction trends are considered only thermodynamic, the reduction reaction with a more positive E 0 is more favorable according to the relationship ΔG = −nFE 0 [26]. However, in the real CO2 electrochemical reactions, in addition to thermodynamic factors, CO2 reduction is also affected by kinetic factors, such as proton concentration [27]. The selectivity of CO2RR during the reaction is also highly influenced by operating conditions and the surface chemical state of the catalyst, such as local pH [27,28], applied potential [25], the type of electrolyte cations [29,30], structure/morphology of catalysts [31–34]. These physical or chemical factors can greatly alter the thermodynamic adsorption energy of the key intermediates and the kinetic energy barrier of the corresponding reactions, thus determining reaction products. The initial CO2 activation is thought to be the first step in the reaction. Even though the precise catalytic activation mechanism of CO2 remains controversial, researchers have proposed several reasonable mechanisms [5,36]. One of the postulated mechanisms of CO2 activation is CO2 obtains one electron to form CO2 •– radical intermediate [37,38]. Due to the high formation energy of CO2 •–, the generation of CO2 •– is considered as the rate-determining step for the whole CO2 reduction reaction. Thus, the efficient fixation of this high-energy intermediate is key to obtaining a high CO2RR rate and energy efficiency [37]. In addition, the binding strength between CO2 •– radical intermediate and catalysts also affects the product distribution. If the CO2 •– intermediate is weakly adsorbed on the catalysts, it is easy to desorb and generate two-electron products. If the CO2 •– intermediate is strongly adsorbed on the catalysts, it will be further reduced to hydrocarbons products [39,40]. Differently, Lee et al. argued that the generation of CO2 •– intermediates required a very negative redox potential (−1.9 V vs. SHE) and made it unstable to occur [25,41]. Consequently, the proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) process, as another possible pathway of CO2 activation, is mentioned [1,5,25,42]. This process involves the simultaneous transfer of protons and electrons, thus avoiding the generation of high-energy CO2 •– radical intermediates and reducing the overpotential. When the target product is a multi-carbon product, the C–C coupling step is generally considered the RDS [1,5,8]. Furthermore, the PCET process facilitates the application of the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) method in CO2 reduction, which has been considered computationally for understanding the mechanism and reaction pathway of CO2RR [43]. After the CO2 activation process, various intermediates, such as *COOH, *CO, are further formed via multiple proton-coupled electron transfers. As one precursor of multielectron transfer products, *CO is often considered as a key descriptor for selecting suitable metal catalysts [44]. For example, Nørskov et al. [45] studied the effect of *CO intermediate free energy on limiting potential (U L) for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. U L is defined as the maximum applied potential required to reduce the Gibbs free energy from a positive value to 0. Theoretically, small U L implies a high catalytic activity. In other words, the relatively smaller U L of a certain product, the better the selectivity of this product. As shown in Fig. 1 (a), the dashed lines represented the dependence of U L on the *CO binding energy for the elementary steps, and the bold lines described a volcano relevant to CO2 reduction to hydrocarbons or alcohols. In the case of metal catalysts for reducing CO2 to CO, such as Au and Ag, U L was much more negative due to their low *CO binding energies, indicating that it was not conducive to generating hydrocarbon products. In the case of Pt and Ni metals, although they had strong adsorption for *CO, they prefer to adsorb *H intermediate to promote hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). Therefore, the *CO adsorption sites were covered with *H, limiting the generation of hydrocarbons products. Unlike other metals, the Cu metal was positioned at the top of the volcano plot. The moderate *CO binding of Cu led to a smaller U L, which allowed for the next step of hydrogenation. The binding affinity of *CO and *H onto the catalyst surface is also used to predict the electrocatalytic trend [7,18]. Rossmeisl et al. [7] used the binding energies of *CO and *H as the descriptor to predict the product distribution. As shown in Fig. 1(b), Cu is the only metal that possessed relatively weaker *H binding and stronger *CO binding, which favors the further reduction to C2+ products. Apart from the key intermediate *CO, the reaction pathway after *CO generation should also be regulated directionally to predict the catalytic activity and C2 product selectivity of Cu-based catalysts. 2.2 Proposed pathways for the reduction of CO2 to C2 products Apart from the formation and adsorption of *CO, the further reduction of *CO deeply affects the selectivity for C2 products over Cu-based catalysts. It has been found 41 different intermediates on the Cu (211) surface, implying the complexity of *CO reduction [46]. To rationally design the Cu-based catalysts for promoting the formation of C2 products, it is significant to identify and control the primary key reaction intermediates, such as *COH, *CHO, and *COCO beyond *CO [19]. In general, the formation of multi-carbon products requires C–C coupling to increase carbon chain length. However, the details of C–C coupling remain controversial due to the complexity of the intermediate structures. For example, C–C coupling occurring through the CO* dimerization is one of the widely accepted mechanisms [14,47–50]. There are also suggestions that the C–C coupling process is accompanied by the PCET process, indicating that the C–C coupling occurs via the reaction of *CO and protonated *CO (*CHO or *COH) [51,52]. Recently, the development of density functional theory (DFT) and advanced operando spectroscopy promotes the understanding of CO2 reduction pathways towards C2 products. Based on that, three widely accepted pathways for CO2RR to C2 products on a Cu surface are proposed, that is, dimerization of *CO, coupling of two *CH2 species (carbene mechanism), and insertion of CO in *CHO species (Fig. 2 ). In the *CO dimerization mechanism, C–C coupling is usually considered as a rate-determining step (RDS) for the whole pathway with the main products being C2H4 and C2H5OH [47,53,54]. In this mechanism, two *CO adsorb on the Cu surface through the electron transfer process to form *C2O2 − intermediate [55]. Normally, the *C2O2 − dimer has two adsorbed forms on the Cu surface as shown in Fig. 2(a). One of these forms is that a C atom and an O atom bind to two adjacent Cu atoms, and the negative charge is mainly distributed on the CO group that is not bonded to Cu. Subsequently, the O atom with more negative charges is protonated to form the *CO–COH intermediate. Another pathway of *C2O2 − dimer formation is that two C atoms bond to two adjacent Cu atoms, meanwhile, the *C2O2 − dimer is stabilized by a charged water layer [53]. After the formation of *C2O2 −, the O atom with more negative charges obtains protons and electrons to generate *CO–COH. For the reduction steps after *CO–COH intermediate, Calle-Vallejo and Koper [55] first proposed the pathway of C2H4 formation through *CO–COH → *CCO on Cu (100). *CCO intermediate is first reduced to *CH–COH, then to *OCH–CH2, and finally C2H4 is formed (green roadmap in Fig. 2a). If the key intermediate of *OCH–CH2 is reduced to *OCH–CH3, C2H5OH can be generated (brown roadmap in Fig. 2a) [56]. Another pathway of *CO–COH reduction involves the generation of *COH–COH (blue roadmap in Fig. 2a) [57,58]. Compared with *CCO, *COH–COH formation is more favorable from the point of view of kinetics, thus this path is more likely to occur [59,60]. The multi-electron reduction of CO2 to C2H4 from this path is proposed: *CO → *COCO → *CO–COH → *COH–COH → *CH–COH → *CH–CH2 → C2H4 [61,62]. Asthagiri et al. [63] proposed a “carbene mechanism” as the main path for generating C2 products. In this mechanism, *COH, as the key intermediate, is first formed by the protonation of the O atom of *CO intermediate (pink roadmap in Fig. 2b). Subsequently, the *COH intermediate is undergone further reduction to *C, which may result in the generation of carbon deposition. This path is explained by DeWulf’s experimental results in which the signals of graphite carbon are detected via in situ XPS and AES [64]. With the further proton-coupled electron transfer, *C is reduced to *CH2. *CH2 is confirmed to be a common intermediate for different hydrocarbons such as C2H4 [65]. If the electrode has an abundant proton supply, *CH2 prefers to convert to C2H4 via *CH2 dimerization [51,66]. If *CH2=C=O is produced deriving from the reaction of *CH2 with CO, it is further reduced to *CH2=CH–OH and finally reduced to C2H5OH [67]. Otherwise CH3COO− can also be formed via *CH2=C=O [17,56]. For the “insertion of CO in *CHO species” mechanism, the C atom in *CO intermediate is protonated to form *CHO intermediate, which is the key intermediate [57] (Fig. 2b). Subsequently, the *CHO binds to the non-adsorbed CO to form *COCHO. In general, the formation of a C–C bond via a non-adsorbed CO insert is the rate-determining step for this mechanism [68]. For the further proton-coupled electron transfer step, hydrogenation of different C atoms leads to different reaction pathways (orange and yellow roadmap in Fig. 2b), and the resulting products are glyoxal/ethanol (for orange roadmap) or ethylene/acetic acids (for yellow roadmap), respectively [61]. This mechanism can also explain the generation of other C2 products such as ethylene, glycol [18]. Numerous experiments have proved that many factors can influence the reaction pathway, such as electrolyte pH value [69], applied potential [57,64], and surface structures [70,71]. Since the protonation process is involved in each step of CO2RR, the local pH may highly affect the electrochemical step. Yeo et al. [72] found that the local pH value increased with the rapid consumption of surface protons, leading to the depletion of dissolved CO2 as well as the enrichment of H+ in the boundary layer. The consumption of CO2 and the reduction of H+ can efficiently increase the total current density of CO2RR [73]. Goddard et al. [60] found that the formation of C2H4 was related to the pH via DFT calculations. At low pH (pH = 1), the C2 pathway was kinetically blocked, while the C1 pathway proceeded through the reaction path of *CO → *COH → CH4. At neutral pH (pH = 7), the generation of C2H4 was advantageous through the reaction path of *CO → *COH → *CO–COH → C2H4. At high pH (pH = 14), *CO dimerization was thermodynamically and kinetically favorable, while the C1 pathway was inhibited. Therefore, pH directly affects the reaction pathway of intermediates, hence affecting the selectivity of products. Like the case of electrolyte’s pH, the selectivity of products is also influenced by applied potentials [56,62]. Goddard et al. [57] proved that the *CO dimerization occurred at a potential lower than −0.6 V on Cu (100), and the following reaction pathway was that *CO–CO → *CO–COH → C2H4. The main product of CO2 reduction was C2H4 in this potential range. From −0.6 to −0.8 V, the competition of *H led to a decrease of *CO in surface coverage, thus decreasing the selectivity of C2H4 and increasing the selectivity of H2. At a more negative potential than −0.8 V, the generation of *CHO was more favorable than *CO dimerization, thus the predominant product was C2H4. Therefore, a rational investigation of experimental conditions should be taken to control the reaction paths, hence improving the catalytic efficiency and controlling the selectivity of CO2RR. 3 Rational design strategies of Cu-based electrocatalysts 3.1 Electronic structure tuning Tuning the electronic structure is regarded to be an efficient strategy to strengthen or weaken the adsorption of reaction intermediates on catalyst atoms via modifying atomic bonding [74]. In most cases, the adsorption energy is considered as a valid parameter for describing the catalytic activity, and the relationship between the adsorption energy and the catalytic activity is shown as a volcano-type plot based on the “Sabatier principle” [74,75]. The most active catalyst is generally located at the top of the volcano plots with moderate intermediate adsorption energy. To better understand the adsorption of the intermediates on catalysts’ surface, d-band center theory is used to reveal the relationship between the electronic structure of catalysts and the adsorption energy of intermediates [76]. Nørskov et al. [77] demonstrated that the energy of d-band center can be used as a “descriptor” to describe the intermediate adsorption energy. The d-band of Cu-based catalysts determined the binding strength between catalytic surface and intermediates. The trend was that the narrower d-band width led to the closer of d-band center toward the Fermi level (E f), implying the stronger adsorption of the intermediates. For example, Yang et al. [78] studied the origin of different product distribution on Au-Cu bimetallic nanoparticles with different Au/Cu ratios. The XPS spectra revealed that the center of the d-band gradually shifted down with increasing Au content, leading to a weak binding strength between the active site and the C atom of *COOH and *CO. In the cases of Cu-based catalysts, the intermediates of CO2RR share a common binding mode to the Cu surface in which the C atom of intermediates binds to the Cu site [78], leading to an inherent linear scaling between the adsorption energy of different intermediates. The linear relationship greatly reduces the independence of product regulation, thus limiting the selectivity of products [79]. Therefore, apart from following the “Sabatier principle”, breaking the linear scaling relationships of intermediates is also necessary for tuning electronic structure to improve the selectivity and regulation of CO2RR. The advanced efforts towards tuning electronic structure on Cu-based catalysts include strain effects, ligand effects, synergistic effects, and chemical states effect. 3.1.1 Strain effect Strain effect can be produced by the stress resulting from lattice mismatch, alloying, and defects, respectively, hence typically impacting lattice parameters and the binding energy of the key intermediates [80]. Lattice strain engineering is a promising route to manipulate electronic structure via tuning the d-band center and adsorption strength of the intermediates. Schnur et al. [81] studied the effect of lattice strain on the d-band center and adsorption energy for transition metals based on DFT calculations. They proved that with the expansion of lattice (tensile strain), the d-band center moves towards E f. Fig. 3 (a) shows the dependence of the d-band center on the lattice strain of different metals. Sc (001), Ti (001), V (110), and Nb (110), whose d-band center at the surface was above their E f, showed a downshift of d-band center upon expansion. Instead, Cr (110) and Mn (111) with d-band center below E f showed that the tensile strain resulted in an upshift of d-band center. The interpretation of this result was that the d band of Cr and Mn was filled with more than half. When they were put under tensile strain, the atomic spacing of the surface atoms increased, resulting in an overlap of the d-orbit and narrower d-band width, thus leading to an upshift of the d-band center. The corresponding changes in the *H and *CO adsorption energies of different metals were also studied as a function of lattice strain. For most metals, the adsorption to *H and *CO became stronger as the lattice expands. As a similar trend to Cr (110) and Mn (111) [82,83], both of d-band center and d-band width showed a linear relationship with the strain in the range of −5% to 5% for Cu (211) and Cu (100) (Fig. 3b) [82], and the tensile strain resulted in an upshift of the d-band center. The binding energy of different intermediates also showed a linear relationship to lattice stress on Cu (211) and Cu (100) facets (Fig. 3c). Fenning et al. [83] studied the effect of lattice strain on model Cu (001) surface. They prepared a series of epitaxial Cu films with (001) surface on single-crystal Si (001) substrate, thus the lattice mismatch between the Cu film and Si substrate led to a tensile strain. Surface-sensitive grazing-incidence X-ray diffraction (GI-XRD) indicated that the tensile strain decreased with the increase of the Cu film thickness. Fig. 3(d) shows that the d-band center of Cu (001) surfaces shifts upward toward fermi level with the increase of tensile strain. Experimental observations and theoretical calculations suggested that the d-band center and the product distribution on Cu (001) surface were quite strain-sensitive (Fig. 3e). The trend was that the increased tensile strain led to an upshift of d-band center, resulting in the increased binding strength of intermediates, thus suppressing the formation of single-carbon products and facilitating multi-carbon products. Binary metal catalysts, including CuAg [84–86], CuNi [87], CuZn [88], and CuPt [89], are also affected by the lattice strain due to the different lattice parameters of two metals. For example, Strasser et al. [89] deposited nanometer-scale thin Cu layers on Pt via electrodeposition and found that the thickness of the Cu layers could significantly be conducted to the generation of C2H4 (Fig. 3f). Since the Pt lattice parameter was ∼8% larger than that of Cu lattice, Pt atoms could increase the atomic distance of the Cu lattice at Cu/Pt interface, resulting in tensile strain. The tensile strain altered the adsorption energy of the intermediates, meanwhile, the increased FE of C2H4 is 3 times higher than that of polycrystalline Cu. Cuenya et al. [85] synthesized Cu2O nanocubes uniformly covered with Ag nanoparticles. The dispersion of the Ag atoms/small clusters on the Cu surface can expand the Cu-Ag distance compared with Cu-Cu, leading to a tensile strain of Cu and stronger binding energy for *CO intermediates, subsequently, enhancing the C–C coupling towards C2 products. In addition, the lattice strain effects can improve both the catalytic activity and the directional selectivity of products on Cu-based catalysts by suppressing the competing HER. For example, Bell et al. [86] prepared CuAg bimetallic catalysts, in which the Cu active centers can be induced the compressive strain via a small amount of Ag (Fig. 3g). The compressive strain can reduce the binding energy of intermediates as well as the coverage of *H, consequently, leading to the suppression of HER (Fig. 3h). Furthermore, the decrease of *H coverage can reduce the rate of C–O bond scission, thus enhancing the oxygenate selectivity observed during CO2RR (Fig. 3i). 3.1.2 Ligand effect Ligand effect can arise from the changes in the chemical properties of the host atom by dopants [80,90]. The second or third atoms were introduced to regulate the electronic structure of host atoms, leading to a downshift or upshift of the d-band center [80]. In heterogeneous catalytic systems, the catalysts are often affected by two electronic effects of ligand effect, ensemble effect, and strain effect simultaneously [90,91], thus it is necessary to clarify the role of different effects for understanding the reaction mechanism and optimizing the catalysts. To distinguish the ligand and ensemble/strain effects, many efforts have been done. For example, in 2001, Nørskov et al. [90] discriminated the ligand effect and ensemble effect via DFT calculations. The results showed that under the influence of the ligand effect, CO bonded to the same metal, implying that only one kind of active site existed. In contrast, the ensemble effect was related to the “mixed” sites, meanwhile, the different components determined the reactivity of the catalyst together. Nanda et al. [91] also studied both strain and ligand effects in bimetallic Cu-Ru and Cu-Ni heterostructures by DFT calculations. They built four models, which was bare Cu1/M1/Cu4 (A1) sandwiched surface, Cu1M5 (A2), Cu2M4 (A3), and Cu3M3 (A4) heterostructures overlayers (brown spheres are Cu atoms; silver spheres are M atoms, M = Ni or Rh), to simulate the pure ligand effect (A1) and the combined of ligand and strain effects (A2, A3, A4) on Cu (211), respectively (Fig. 4 a). For the model of Cu1/M1/Cu4 (A1), M shared the common lattice parameters of Cu, therefore no strain was induced and the top Cu monolayer (ML) was affected only by the ligand effect. For the model of Cu i /M j (A2, A3, A4), both the ligand and strain effects acted on the Cu layer. As increasing the number of Cu MLs from one to three, the ligand effect was filtered out and the strain effect dominated at i = 3. By analyzing the adsorption energy of the intermediates on these four models, the individual contributions of ligand and strain effects can be understood. Fig. 4(b–e) show the relative binding energies of the key intermediates on A1–A4 surfaces. The more positive values of binding energy were defined as a weaker binding of intermediates. It showed that the ligand effect can enhance the binding energies of all intermediates compared with the strain effect on Cu (211) surface. Introducing dopants is a widely used approach to obtain the ligand effect [92,93]. As shown in Fig. 4(f), Ni was introduced into Cu lattice [94]. The valence band spectra (VBS) of XPS showed that the d-band center shifted up with increasing Ni content on NiCu surface due to the ligand effect. In addition, the non-metal doping on Cu-X surfaces also led to the ligand effect, thus resulting in a change in the charge distribution around Cu. Qiao et al. [92] calculated the adsorption energy of some key intermediates for C2 products, such as *OCHCH2 and *OCHCH3. The results showed that the non-metal doping on Cu-X surfaces altered the O affinity of Cu site by adjusting the charge distribution, therefore, causing the different product distribution compared with the pure Cu surface (Fig. 4g). 3.1.3 Ensemble effect Ensemble effect is also called synergistic effect, resulting from the coexistence of metal and dopants with dissimilar mechanistic functionalities [90]. When we focus on the ensemble effect, it means that we need to consider more than one active site to analyze the reaction mechanism [95–98]. Although the ensemble effect has been widely used for CO2RR, the origin of the ensemble effect and the nature of the active phase are not well understood for most multi-component catalysts. Ramírez et al. [96] revealed the origin of the ensemble effect of copper-indium catalysts by spatially resolved characterization techniques. To design catalysts with well-defined composition and geometry, they deposited microscale In or In2O3 structures on Cu or Cu2O surfaces based on microfabrication. As shown in Fig. 5 (a), the as-deposited In or In2O3 was distributed over the substrate in a shape of regular circular island. Fig. 5(b) shows the elemental distribution of indium over individual islands before and after CO2RR. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy coupled to SEM (SEM-EDX) showed that a bimetallic phase was formed at the Cu2O and indium source interfaces, thus deriving the ensemble effect. The ensemble effect is often discussed in the tandem systems due to the mixed active sites. Tandem catalysis is an important strategy to break the linear relationships between different intermediates because of the ability for disassembling the complex CO2 reduction reactions into multiple independent steps [99]. In general, the different active sites of the tandem catalysts synergistically enhance the formation of C2 products via making full use of *CO intermediate [97,100–102]. Improving the adsorption concentration and adsorption strength of *CO intermediate near the mixed active sites is the key factor in utilizing the ensemble effect. For example, Cao et al. [97] dispersed Cu nanoparticles on the porphyrinic triazine framework anchored with atomically isolated nickel-nitrogen sites (PTF(Ni)) and constructed PTF(Ni)/Cu tandem electrocatalyst with two catalytic sites. Based on the operando ATR-FTIR spectroscopy and DFT calculations, they concluded that PTF(Ni) sites facilitated the generation of CO and increased the concentration of CO, meanwhile, the high concentration of CO migrated easily to the neighboring Cu NPs sites. The Cu sites were favorable for the next C–C coupling reaction and reached a high C2H4 faraday efficiency of 57.3% at −1.1 V vs. RHE (Fig. 5c). The comparison of C2H4 faraday efficiency for CO2RR and CORR (electroreduction of CO) on PTF(Ni)/Cu and PTF/Cu catalysts, as shown in Fig. 5(d), highlighted the importance of PTF(Ni) sites for generating CO in-situ. In addition, it has been proved that the core–shell structures can enhance the bonding strength of *CO [101,103,104]. Huang et al. [101] fabricated the Cu@Ag core-shell nanoparticles (NPs) with different silver layer thicknesses resulting in reducing CO2 to C2 products (Fig. 5e). Electrochemical tests and CO adsorption capacity analyses demonstrated that the origin of the enhanced C2 products selectivity can be attributed to the ensemble effect of Ag shell and Cu core. On one hand, a moderately thick Ag shell facilitated producing a high concentration of *CO and promoted CO spillover to Cu sites (Fig. 5f). On the other hand, the Cu/Ag interfaces enhanced the bonding strength of CO, which favored the further reduction to C2 products. Ag shell and Cu core synergistically improved the selectivity of C2 products. Yeo et al. [105] proved that the ensemble effect can also affect the product distribution on bimetallic Cu x Zn oxides. During the CO2RR, the Cu x Zn oxides were reduced to a metallic state, which acted as the real active sites for reducing CO2 to ethanol or ethylene. Based on that, they proposed a two-site mechanism, in which Zn sites acted as a CO-producer, simultaneously, Cu sites reduced CO to ethanol or ethylene. Fig. 5(g) shows that the ratio of ethanol and ethylene varied depending on the amounts of Zn, implying the importance of the CO-producing site. 3.1.4 Chemical states effect Oxide-derived copper (OD-Cu) has been proved to be an efficient catalyst for CO2RR [15,106,107]. During CO2RR, oxidized copper tends to be reduced to Cu0 or Cu+. The charge of the Cu site affects the adsorption strength of H2O molecules, CO2 molecules, and intermediates, hence influencing the CO2RR performance [108]. Due to the rapid redox of Cu during the CO2RR process, the real valence state of Cu (Cuδ+) is still controversial, limiting the understanding of the catalytic mechanism of OD-Cu. In this section, we discuss three mainstream views on the valence state of Cu. Firstly, Baltrusaitis et al. [109] believed that oxidized copper was reduced to Cu0 during CO2RR. Thermodynamically, the redox potential of Cu (E 0 = −0.36 V vs. NHE) is more positive than the operating potential of CO2RR (< −1.0 V vs. NHE), thus oxidized copper should be reduced to Cu0 [110]. They studied the surface structure and product distribution of Cu2O films via in-situ mass spectroscopy combined with ex-situ X-ray diffraction data. The results showed that Cu2O films were reduced to nanoparticulate Cu0 before CO2 reduction, and the coverage/number density/size of the Cu nanoparticles determined the reduction products. Ager et al. [111] investigated the stability of copper oxides by 18O isotope labeling. They prepared 18O enriched OD-Cu catalysts and obtained a high selectivity of C2+ products (FE = 60%) for up to 5 h in 0.1 M KHCO3 at −1.0 V vs. RHE (Fig. 6 a). The residual 18O content in OD-Cu was then analyzed with ex-situ secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS). When the reaction lasted only 10 min at −1.0 V vs. RHE, only < 1% of 18O was found in the catalysts (Fig. 6b), suggesting that Cu oxide layers were fully reduced to Cu0 during CO2RR. Han et al. [112] also investigated the chemical states of Cu on Cu-based electrodes via focused ion beam (FIB)-fabricated specimen and electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS). They prepared two Cu-based electrodes with mixed oxidation states, which were HQ-Cu (containing Cu, Cu2O, CuO) and AN-Cu (containing Cu, Cu (OH)2). The structural analysis revealed that both two Cu-based electrodes were fully reduced to metallic Cu at the steady stage of the CO2RR, regardless of the initial state. The second viewpoint is that the Cu+ plays an important role in CO2RR. For example, Sargent et al. [113] tracked the oxidation state of Cu on electrodeposited Cu (ERD Cu) using in situ soft X-ray absorption spectroscopy under CO2RR conditions. The experimental results revealed that the sharp morphology of ERD Cu can stabilize the presence of Cu+ at highly negative reducing potentials, and the presence of Cu+ promoted the formation of C2H4 (Fig. 6c and d). Cuenya et al. [114] also proved that Cu+ species remained on the surface during the reaction. They treated the Cu catalysts via O2 plasma to create mixed-valence states (Cu0, Cu+, Cu2+) on the surface. Based on in situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy and cross-sectional scanning transmission electron microscopy measurement, they concluded that copper oxides were resistant for reduction, and Cu+ species remained on the surface during the reaction. Further, they also found the high local pH could help stabilize Cu+ by shifting the overpotential for Cu2O reduction (Fig. 6e and f). Finally, the coexistence of Cu0 and Cu+ at the surface of the Cu catalysts is also widely studied [15,107,115–117]. For example, Goddard et al. [115] believed that the presence of a thin suboxide structure below the Cu surface, which led to a mix of Cu+ and Cu0 on the surface, was essential to reduce CO2. The combination of ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (APXPS) experiments and DFT calculations proved that Cu+ and Cu0 regions acted synergistically to promote *CO dimerization and suppress C1 pathways, thereby boosting catalyst selectivity of C2 products. In addition, the DFT calculations showed that the Cu+ sites provided strong H2O adsorption energy, which facilitated the stabilization of CO2 via hydrogen bonds. Sargent et al. [117] also demonstrated the coexistence of Cu+ and Cu0 on the boron-doped Cu catalysts. Boron atoms induced the coexistence of Cu+ and Cu0 sites through the partial electron transfer from Cu to boron, thus resulting in an average Cu valence state (Cuδ+) of + 0.35. The special Cuδ+ promoted the CO adsorption and dimerization, leading to high faradaic efficiency for C2 hydrocarbons of ∼80%. Apart from the oxide-derived Cu-based electrocatalysts, halide-derived (F, Cl, Br, and I) Cu-based electrocatalysts have been demonstrated to exhibit outstanding CO2RR performance due to the regulation of the valence on Cuδ+ species by the halogen atoms [9,118–120]. For example, Yang et al. [9] investigated the effect of halogen ions on Cu4(OH)6FCl nanosheets catalysts. The results showed that the stable Cu0-Cu+ sites were the real active sites of CO2RR and favored the high C2+ faradaic efficiency of 53.8%. The residual-chlorine electrocatalysts induced a high content of Cu+ species and promoted the catalytic stability in long-term electrocatalysis over 240 h. Qiao et al. [119] prepared the iodide-derived copper (ID-Cu) and found a great ethane selectivity. To obtain a deeper understanding of the CO2 to ethane mechanism, they combined the electrochemistry with in situ XAFS and Raman spectroscopy and found that the trace iodine species on the Cu surface can keep Cu active sites for the optimized oxidation state, thus stabilizing the key intermediate *OCH2CH3, leading to enhancement of ethane selectivity. Wu et al. [118] also observed a significant increase in C2+ faradaic efficiency of 72% on the Br-doped Cu-thiol interface. A combination of theoretical calculations and experimental results showed that the Br species in Cu can stabilize high-valence Cu species and steer the selectivity toward C2 products. 3.2 Surface structure tuning Due to the complexity of CO2RR, the property of Cu-based catalysts is always composition-dependence [121], which cannot simply explain their catalytic activity only by d-band center or electronic structure effect. Apart from electronic structure, surface structures, including size [122,123], grain boundary [1,124], defects [56,125], and crystal faces [100,126], are deeply affecting the activity and selectivity of CO2 reduction on Cu electrocatalysts. 3.2.1 Size effect The particle size of Cu-based catalysts can significantly modulate the catalytic activity via changing the number of low-coordinated sites (such as atoms on the corners, along the edges) on the surface [13,121,127]. Chorkendorf et al. [128] studied the size effect of Pt nanoparticles and found that a decrease in particle size brought about an increase in low-coordinated sites due to the increasing curvature of surfaces. Generally, the increasing low-coordinated surface sites can strengthen the binding energy of certain intermediates [129]. To further study the relationship between size and performance of Cu catalysts, Strasser et al. [13] built a model of spherical Cu nanoparticles (2–15 nm) to gain insight into the origin of the particle size effect. The result showed that the decreasing of particle size led to a significant increase of low-coordinated sites, thus resulting in stronger chemisorption of CO2, CO, atomic H, and CO y H x . However, for the nanoparticles below 5 nm, the increasing low-coordinated sites led to ultra-high binding energy of the intermediates, which was not conducive to the generation of hydrocarbon. Therefore, to obtain C2 products, very small (< 3 nm) nanoscale Cu catalysts should be avoided for tuning moderate adsorption energy of key intermediates. Hensen et al. [130] analyzed the influence of particle size effects on different sizes of Cu n clusters (Cu13, Cu15, Cu19, Cu55, Cu79) via theoretical calculation. DFT calculations revealed a strong size-dependent activity for Cu n clusters, in which Cu19 clusters with a moderate number of low coordination sites showed the best activity for CO2 hydrogenation. The balance of plane- and edge- sites is also a key factor of size effect affecting CO2RR activity [123,131]. Buonsanti et al. [122] explored the size effect of Cu nanocrystals (NCs) via analyzing three different sizes of Cu NC cubes (24, 44, and 63 nm). Electrochemical tests showed that the 44 nm side length of Cu NC cubes exhibited the best selectivity for ethylene (FEC2H4 = 50%) (Fig. 7 a). To explore the origin of activity for Cu NC cubes, a simple model was used to derive the statistics of surface atoms for Cu NC cubes (Fig. 7b). It showed that 44 nm Cu NC cubes had an optimal balance between plane- and edge- sites, which was crucial to maximize the ethylene selectivity. Cuenya et al. [132] also found that the balance of plane- and edge- sites can affect the selectivity and stability of large Cu cubes. They prepared a series of large Cu cubes with different sizes (580, 320, 220 nm). In general, the larger Cu cubes surface has a larger ratio of flat surface sites to corner/edge sites, which can provide a moderate number of low coordination sites. As shown in Fig. 7(c), the larger Cu cubes of 580 nm have a higher initial total CO2RR FE of approximately 75%, indicating that the optimization of the plane- and edge- sites is important for improving the selectivity of CO2 reduction. In addition, operando electrochemical atomic force microscopy (EC-AFM) was used to investigate the causes of the reduced selectivity over time. As shown in Fig. 7(d), the size decreasing and the loss of sharp corners/edges of Cu cubes were observed in the first hour of the reaction, implying the instability of corners or edges sites. Therefore, appropriate high content of flat surface sites can favor the stability of the catalysts. 3.2.2 Crystal facets effect The exposure facets have been proven more reactive for CO2RR and further control over the selectivity [133–137]. Hori et al. [126,138] investigated the different surfaces of Cu and found that Cu (100) surface primarily formed C2H4, while Cu (110) and Cu (111) surfaces were predominantly to form CH4. Koper [55] explained the reaction mechanism of C2 products (C2H4, EtOH, and MeCHO) formation on Cu (100) via theoretical calculations. They found that *CO dimerization was more conducive to occurring on Cu (100). After that, the *C2O2 intermediate was formed and further reduced to C2H4 and EtOH by multi-step of PCEF. Nørskov et al. [139] simulated *CO dimerization process on Cu (100) and (111) crystal faces. They found that the energy barrier for the *CO dimerization on Cu (100) was only 0.33 eV, which was lower than that on Cu (111) (0.68 eV). For the next hydrogenation step, the energy barrier on the Cu (100) surface was also lower than that on Cu (111). These results demonstrated that the catalyst facets significantly affected the reaction path, thus affecting product selectivity. Several crystal surfaces may exist simultaneously to form high-index crystal planes and exhibit excellent CO2 electroreduction activity [48,140–142]. For example, Gong et al. [48] prepared the Cu (OH)2-derived Cu catalysts with rich stepped Cu (110) and Cu (100) (Fig. 8 a), which were assembled into Cu (210) (=2 (110) × (100)) and Cu (310) (=3 (110) × (100)). Compared with the catalysts exposing only one crystal surface, the Cu (OH)2-derived Cu catalysts rich in high-index crystal planes exhibited a high FE of 58% for C2H4 and 87% for C2+ hydrocarbons at −0.54 V vs. RHE (Fig. 8c and d). DFT calculations showed that Cu (110) regions in (210) and (310) crystal faces facilitated CO adsorption, meanwhile, Cu (100) regions in (210) and (310) crystal faces promoted the C–C coupling to C2 products (Fig. 8b). Similarly, Huang et al. [140] also proved that Cu (511), which was assembled by 3 (100) and (111), showed high selectivity of C2H4 and good stability over 200 h. DFT calculations revealed that the stepped surface led to a high local concentration of *CO and a higher barrier for the C1 products, thus improving the selectivity of C2 products. 3.2.3 Defects effect Many efforts have proved that defects are an effective factor to regulate the physical/chemical properties of the surface structure [143–147]. Zheng et al. [143] reported copper oxide nanodendrites with rich surface oxygen vacancies (CuO x –Vo) catalysts via a facile electrochemical deposition method. It has been found that the existence of surface oxygen vacancies can greatly improve the C2H4 selectivity (FE = 63%) while suppressing H2 evolution. The calculated free energies indicated that the oxygen vacancies on the CuO x surfaces could increase the binding energy of *CO and *COH while decreasing the binding energy of *CH2, thus leading to the efficient formation of C2H4. Zhang et al. [145] reported Cu nanosheets with nanoscaled defects (n-CuNS) by an electrochemical reduction method. As displayed in Fig. 9 (a–c), numerous pits (2–14 nm in size) are obtained on each Cu nanosheet and the atomic defects on the pits are increasing from the edge of the pit to the center. Electrochemical analysis showed that n-CuNS catalyst presented an enhancement total current density of 60 mA cm−2 and a higher ethylene FE of 83.2% in a wide potential range of −0.88 to −1.48 V (vs. RHE) than that of Cu nanosheets and Cu nanoparticles. To further explore the function of the defects, they compared the adsorption energy of key intermediates (*CO and *OCCO) via DFT calculations (Fig. 9d), and the results revealed that the nanoscaled defect on Cu facilitated the adsorptions of CO, thus promoting C–C coupling for ethylene formation. Sargent et al. [146] discussed the effects of defects on product distribution. They prepared a modified Cu2S core with Cu surface vacancies (Cu2S-Cu-V) and obtained a high alcohol FE of 32% and a production rate of 126 ± 5 mA cm−2. It was also found that the surface copper vacancies can promote the product transition from ethylene to ethanol (Fig. 9e). Combined with a further DFT calculation, they pointed out that the vacancies on Cu2S-Cu-V increased the energy barrier in the ethylene pathway, moving the reaction toward the ethanol pathway, thus leading to efficient ethanol production. Grain boundary (GB) is one of the defective structures in crystalline materials. It has proved that the grain boundary can lead to the production of high-energy surfaces and improve the electrical conductivity and mechanical properties of materials, thus facilitating catalytic performance [124,148]. In recent years, introducing grain boundary into Cu-based catalysts has been widely used in CO2RR [19,149–151]. For example, Gong et al. [22] prepared a grain boundary-rich copper catalyst (GB-Cu) by the additive-control electrodeposition (PVP was used as an additive) (Fig. 9f) and obtained a high selectivity of 70% for ethylene and ethanol. Based on in situ ATR-SEIRAS characterizations, it was found that the existence of GBs enhanced *CO adsorption. DFT calculation was also used to explore the impact of the GBs formation. As shown in Fig. 9(g and h), the Σ3 twin boundary was chosen to simulate rich-GBs Cu nanoparticles. The calculation of CO binding energies in different sites revealed that GBs enhanced the CO binding energy of their surrounding atoms, thus promoting C–C coupling. Wei et al. [149] also obtained abundant grain boundaries by reducing Mo8 modified cubic fragmented Cu submicron particles on titanium dioxide nanotube arrays (TNA) (Mo8@Cu/TNA). It was found that the existence of GBs promoted the generation of C2 productions and reached the outstanding acetate formation faradaic efficiency of 48.68%. 3.3 Coordination environment tuning The tuning of the coordination environment is an important strategy for designing high-performance metal-complex catalysts on CO2RR [152]. Cu-complex catalysts are usually composed of metal centers and ligands. Due to the well-defined active centers, high Cu atomic utilization, and large selection of ligands, it is very convenient to design the structure to achieve good performance [153–156]. In general, controlling the distance of Cu sites and the number of ligands can effectively adjust the coordination environment of catalysts. The changes in the coordination microenvironment of the catalytic activity center can impact the structural geometry of active sites, thus leading to a significant optimization of the intermediate adsorption energies and selectivity for specific hydrocarbon products [156–161]. In this section, we focus on the effects of Cu-Cu distance and restructuring on the electrochemical reduction of CO2 to C2 products. 3.3.1 Cu-Cu distance For Cu-complex catalysts, the Cu centers have been considered as active sites for CO2RR, in which the near-range coordination environment can effectively regulate the catalytic activity. In general, due to the lack of neighboring Cu sites on Cu-complex catalysts, it is different to occur C–C coupling for reducing CO2 to C2 products. For example, Cu-N2, Cu-N3, and Cu-N4 sites have proved to facilitate the formation of C1 products [157–159]. It is noteworthy that reducing the distance of the Cu sites can effectively promote the C–C coupling [160–163]. Zheng et al. [160] found that the distance between the atomically dispersed Cu-N x species can influence the product distribution. They prepared the Cu–N-C catalysts with different concentrations of Cu-N x by controlling the pyrolysis temperature (Fig. 10 a and b). When the Cu–N-C catalyst was calcined at 900 °C, it had a high Cu loading density (4.9% mol), and Cu atoms of the Cu-N2 sites were close to each other, which favored C–C coupling, resulting in C2H4 as a main CO2 reduction product. In contrast, at a Cu concentration of lower than 2.4% mol, the distance between Cu-N2 species was too large to facilitate the generation of C2H4. The binding energies of different intermediates for producing C2H4 on Cu-N4 and Cu-N2 sites were calculated by DFT (Fig. 10c). The results showed that two adjacent Cu-N2 sites can better synergistically promote the *CO dimerization than the isolated Cu-N2 sites. Zhang et al. [162] induced dual-Cu sites in boron imidazolate frameworks (BIFs) which varied bridging ligands and achieved high faradic efficiency of C2H4 products (FE of 11.3%). Based on XANES/XPS characterizations and electrocatalytic results, they concluded that the dual-Cu sites assisted C–C coupling, and the ligands led to the charge enrichment of Cu centers, thus improving CO2RR performance towards C2 products (Fig. 10d). Lan et al. [163] compared four Cu-based one-dimensional chain-like compounds (Cu-PzH, Cu-PzCl, Cu-PzBr, and Cu-PzI), which possessed different halogen atoms on the Pz (Pz = pyrazole) ligands. As shown in Fig. 10(e), with the variations of different electronegative halogen atoms occupied the 4-position of pyrazole (4-XPz) (X = H, Cl, Br, I), the regular ratio FECH4:FEC2H4 changed from 1:6.5, 1.0:2.3, 1.0:1.2 to 1.0:0.3. It was found that the polarization of halogen changed the distance and angle of Cu-Cu sites (DCu-Cu and βCu-Cu) due to the variations of electronegativity in different halogen atoms (Fig. 10f). As the electronegativity of the halogen atoms decreased, the distance Cu-Cu sites increased, causing a decrease of the *CO···*COH distance, thus limiting C–C coupling for generating C2H4. 3.3.2 Reconstruction In recent years, it has been demonstrated that the catalysts reconstruction, which causes the changes of structure and composition of catalysts under CO2RR conditions, can lead to the generation of new phases, thus significantly improving the catalyst activity [161,164–168]. Fontecave et al. [161] prepared the Cu0.5NC catalysts with Cu-N4 sites, in which Cu atoms were well-defined isolated in the nitrogen-doped conductive carbon matrix (Fig. 11 a). As shown in Fig. 11(b and c), in-situ XANES and EXAFS demonstrated that Cu-N4 sites were observed to convert into very small metallic Cu nanoparticles during electrolysis. These little Cu nanoparticles were the origin of the high activity and obtained a high faradaic efficiency of 55% for ethanol at −1.2 V vs. RHE in 0.1 M CsHCO3. Further studies were also proved that the restructuring behavior was reversible, and the Cu nanoparticles were oxidized to initially isolated Cu sites after removing the applied voltage. Yang et al. [165] established a CuN2Cl2 structure by introducing Cu into a rationally designed covalent triazine framework (CTF-B) and obtained a FE of 30.6% for producing C2H4 during the CO2RR (Fig. 11d). The time-dependent operando EXAFS measurement showed that the single Cu-X sites converted into Cu clusters within the activation time, and Cu clusters were the real active sites (Fig. 11e). The reconstruction was also been used to explore the relationship between coordination numbers and product distribution under real CO2RR conditions. Sargent et al. [166] prepared Cu clusters with different coordination numbers via the reconstruction on copper (II) phthalocyanine (CuPc) and a carbon nanoparticle (CNP) moderator strategy was designed to prevent the agglomeration of low coordination numbers Cu clusters. As shown in Fig. 11(f–h), DFT calculations showed that the reaction energy for *CO to form *CHO via the hydrogenation step decreased with the decrease of coordination numbers, resulting in the favorable generation of CH4. Differently, no significant changes occurred on the reaction energy associated with C–C coupling for the C2 generation. The experimental results showed that Cu catalyst with high coordination numbers was favorable for C2H4 production. 4 Summary and perspectives The increasing CO2 emissions have caused serious damage to the ecological environment. Among various techniques to reduce CO2 concentration in the atmosphere, the conversion of CO2 into fuel and industrial raw materials by electrochemical reduction is an important view towards sustainable development. The advantages of CO2RR include: (1) the reaction conditions are mild and controllable; (2) CO2 can be converted into more economically valuable chemical feedstock or fuel, thereby alleviating the energy crisis; (3) the renewable electrical energy can be stored as higher energy–density chemical energy via CO2RR. However, the electroreduction CO2 reaction is limited by the chemical inertia of CO2, the low solubility of CO2 in the aqueous solution, the competition of hydrogen reduction reaction, and multiple reaction pathways, resulting in a huge challenge to generate a single product with a high yield. Furthermore, the generation of C2 products requires the C–C coupling of intermediates with one-carbon, such as *CO and *CHO, it is more complex than the synthesis of C1 product. Therefore, choosing a suitable catalyst is particularly important for the generation of C2 products. Among various electrochemical catalysts, Cu-based electrocatalysts are the most promising catalysts for reducing CO2 to hydrocarbons, alcohols, aldehydes, and other C2 products. Table 2 presents a summary of CO2 reduction performance over different Cu-based catalysts. In this review, we summarized the recent advances in the reaction mechanism of CO2RR and provided three strategies to promote the generation of C2 products on Cu-based catalysts. In the summary of the reaction mechanism of CO2RR, three reaction mechanisms, including the dimerization of *CO, the “carbene mechanism”, and the insertion of CO in *CHO species, respectively, are categorized based on the differences in intermediates of C–C coupling. For the dimerization of the *CO mechanism, C2H4 is the most common C2 product and the initial C–C coupling step of *CO is considered as the rate-limiting step. For the “carbene mechanism”, *CH2 is the common intermediate for C–C coupling. The detailed reaction process of the “carbene mechanism” is as follows. *COH is first formed by the direct hydrogenation of *CO, subsequently, *COH is further reduced to *CH2, which can be dimerized for C2H4 or generate ethanol through the further PCET process. For the insertion of CO in *CHO species mechanism, *CHO is derived from the protonation of *CO, meanwhile, C–C bond is formed by the insertion of non-adsorbed CO. Based on the previous studies, we have noted that the current studies focused mainly on the steps of CO hydrogenation and C–C coupling, while the subsequent steps are much less investigated. The subsequent steps are directly related to product selectivity. Thus, it is crucial to understand the effects of the catalyst structure and different experimental parameters such as pH and potential ranges on subsequent intermediates. Furthermore, the in situ characterization techniques, including X-ray absorption spectroscopy, surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy, and surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy should be further developed to identify various intermediates under the reaction conditions. The simulated calculations closer to the real electrochemical environment should also be investigated for an in-depth understanding of the catalytic mechanism. The study of the structure-performance relationship is essential to explore the way in which catalysts affect electrocatalytic activity. In this review, we discussed three strategies for boosting Cu-based catalysts performance towards C2 products, which are tuning electronic structure, surface structure, and coordination environment. In general, Cu-based catalysts have multiple components, and the components are often affected by strain effect, ligand effect, and synergistic effect. Therefore, the distinguishment of the difference between the three effects can effectively adjust the catalyst electronic structure, optimize the intermediate adsorption energies and regulate product distribution. The surface structures of Cu-based catalysts, such as the oxidation state, size, and crystal faces, also affect the CO2 reduction activity significantly. However, the surface of the catalysts is often reconstructed under the reaction conditions, thus making it difficult to determine the real active sites. In order to better understand the relationship between the material structures and catalytic activity, in situ electrochemical/spectral/nuclear magnetic/chromatographic characterization techniques should be vigorously further developed to detect the structural changes of the catalyst. Cu-based molecular catalysts have become a promising catalyst for CO2RR because of their controllable ligands and coordination numbers. However, the key problem of molecular catalysts design is to stabilize the activity center at a more negative voltage. The effective idea to solve this problem is to reconstruct the catalysts by using the instability of the central atoms. What’s more, the metal sites are often distributed as single atoms in molecular catalysts, which is not conducive to C–C coupling. Therefore, apart from the design of ligands type and coordination numbers, the distance between two adjacent metal centers in complex catalysts should affect C2 products. In brief, there is still an extremely broad space to explore high efficient Cu-based catalysts of electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. Although significant achievement has been achieved for designing Cu-based catalysts, it remains a challenge to produce efficient and economic catalysts. To meet the requirements of practical applications, the structural design and preparation of Cu-based catalysts should also be more considered from an economic perspective. Many reports have shown that the electrochemical performance of the catalysts strongly influences the underlying economic viability of CO2RR. For example, the current density is one of the most influential technical parameters to impact the cost because the low current density requires the greater electrode area and equipment, resulting in increased costs. To increase the current density, it is necessary to increase the load density of active sites on the Cu-based catalysts. In addition, improving the catalyst conductivity to facilitate charge transfer and using gas diffusion electrodes to promote CO2 diffusion can also effectively increase the current density. The overpotential is regarded as another technical parameter affecting the economic viability of CO2RR. The decrease of overpotential can effectively reduce the electrolytic energy consumption and improve the energy conversion efficiency. The RDS reflects the kinetic characteristics of the entire electrode process and is closely related to the overpotential. To decrease the overpotential, it is critical to identify the RDS combining DFT calculation and in-situ characterization techniques, further choose the appropriate catalysts to reduce the reaction energy barrier of the RDS. Due to the structural disruption and toxicity of catalysts at a negative potential, long-term durability is an important indicator to ensure the practicability of Cu-based catalysts. The pore structure can effectively inhibit the separation and reunion of catalysts, thus improving the catalyst stability. The introduction of supports can fix the catalysts and protect the active centers from electrolyte corrosion, favoring the long-term durability of the Cu-based catalysts. Moreover, the synthesis methods of catalysts should be simple, environmentally friendly, and conform to the application of industrial production. In conclusion, great efforts have been made in the field of reducing CO2 to C2 products on Cu-based catalysts in the past few years, but it still exists numerous challenges to use them for practical production. Using more advanced synthesis and characterization methods, combining theoretical calculation with experimental research, further exploring new Cu-based materials, are expected to make more breakthroughs in the field of electrocatalytic reduction CO2. Shuo Liu received her bachelor’s degree at Tianjin University of Science and Technology in 2017. She is currently a Ph.D. candidate at Tianjin University under the supervision of Professor Jie Sun. Her research focuses on controllable synthesis of electrocatalytic materials for electrochemical CO2 reduction and O2 reduction. Baoshan Zhang received his bachelor’s degree at North University of China (2018). He is currently a Ph.D. candidate at Tianjin University under the supervision of Professor Jie Sun. His research focuses on the design, synthesis, and application of nickel-based electrocatalytic materials. Lihong Zhang is an associate professor of chemical engineering and technology at Tianjin University, China. She received her Ph.D. degree from Beijing University of Chemical Technology. Her current research interests focus on the controlled preparation of 2-dimensional nanolayered materials, catalytic conversion of low alkanes, and electro-catalysis. Jie Sun is a professor of chemical engineering and technology at Tianjin University, China. She received her Ph.D. degree from Beijing University of Chemical Technology in 2013. She worked as a postdoctoral at Stanford University from 2013 to 2017. Her current research interests focus on the development of electrocatalysis and electrochemical energy storage, including Li-ion, Na-ion, K-ion batteries, lithium-sulfur batteries, and nanomaterial-based electrocatalysis.

coredata.dc:description: Electrochemical reduction of CO2 (CO2RR) to high value-added chemicals is an effective way to remove excess CO2 from the atmosphere. Due to the unique propensity of Cu for valuable hydrocarbons, Cu-based electrocatalysts are the most potential catalysts that allow the conversion of CO2 into a variety of C2 products such as ethylene and ethanol. Rational design of Cu-based catalysts can improve their directional selectivity to C2 products. Hence, in this review, we summarize the recent progress in the mechanistic studies of Cu-based catalysts on reducing CO2 to C2 products. We focus on three key strategies for efficiently enhancing electrocatalytic performance of Cu-based catalysts, including tuning electronic structure, surface structure, and coordination environment. The correlation between the structural characteristics of Cu-based catalysts and their activity and selectivity to C2 products is discussed. Finally, we discuss the challenges in the field of CO2 electroreduction to C2 products and provide the perspectives to design efficient Cu-based catalysts in the future.
